summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Bobbi C. Sternheim, to Judge Nathan, detailing ongoing interference with attorney-client communications at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). The letter alleges breaches of confidentiality in video teleconferences (VTCs), unauthorized third-party access, and restrictive conditions that hamper Maxwell's trial preparation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case, currently detained at MDC. The letter details restrictions on her attorney-client communications and her ability to prepare for trial.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is reporting to the court about interference with attorney-client communications and restrictive conditions at MDC.

persons.name: J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to him requesting court intervention.

persons.name: Leon
persons.context: An MDC technician tasked with dealing with Ghislaine Maxwell's electronics issues. He was reportedly present during a breach of the Zoom room used for attorney-client VTCs.

connections.description: Sternheim is the defense attorney representing Maxwell, as evidenced by her detailed advocacy regarding Maxwell's detention conditions and communication rights.
Leon is an MDC technician tasked with handling Maxwell's electronics issues, indicating a professional, institutional relationship.

events.title: VTC Monitor Placed in Box
events.description: The MDC placed the VTC monitor inside a box with a screen, severely impacting Maxwell's ability to see counsel and documents. This issue was later resolved.

events.title: MDC Changes VTC Platform
events.description: MDC Legal informed defense counsel that VTCs must switch from the defense's WebEx platform to an MDC-provided Zoom platform, citing complaints from Maxwell.

events.title: Zoom Room Breach
events.description: Third parties accessed the Zoom room used by Maxwell and her counsel for a VTC. This breach was reported to and witnessed by MDC staff.

events.title: Restricted In-Person Visit
events.description: During an in-person legal visit, Sternheim and Maxwell were told they could not pass documents, frustrating the productivity of the four-hour meeting.

events.title: Concern About VTC Recording
events.description: The defense expressed concern to MDC Legal that VTCs between Maxwell and counsel may have been tape recorded by the MDC. No response was received.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Defense counsel alleges the MDC changed the VTC platform from WebEx to Zoom due to Maxwell's complaints about a third-party participant named 'NER/BRO' appearing on screen and adjusting settings.
A breach occurred on August 12th when third parties accessed the Zoom room used for Maxwell's attorney-client VTCs, which was reported to MDC staff.
Maxwell's ability to prepare for trial is severely hampered by restrictions on document sharing during VTCs and in-person visits, and limits on the quantity of legal materials she can use.
The defense has raised concerns that the MDC may have been recording attorney-client VTCs, a serious potential violation of confidentiality and constitutional rights.
As of August 18, 2021, VTCs had not resumed for three days, and the MDC had provided no information regarding the delays or security concerns.
